answer_html: \(D_{\widehat{\mathbf{u}}} T(1,2,-1)=25\sqrt2 e^{-9}.\) Its units are \(\displaystyle {}\text{C}/\text{m}\).
hints_html:
Recall that the directional derivative of a scalar function f in the direction \(\mathbf{u}\) is

\[\begin{aligned} D_uf=\nabla{f}\cdot\hat{\mathbf{u}}\end{aligned}\]

where \(\hat{\mathbf{u}}\) is a unit vector.

What is the direction vector \(\mathbf{u}\) that we need?
hints_latex: What is the direction vector $\mathbf{u}$ that we need?
hints_raw:
Recall that the directional derivative of a scalar function f in the direction <math>\mathbf{u}</math> is

:<math>
D_uf=\nabla{f}\cdot\hat{\mathbf{u}}
</math>

where <math> \hat{\mathbf{u}} </math> is a unit vector.
What is the direction vector <math>\mathbf{u}</math> that we need?
question: 4 (a)
sols_html:
For \(\displaystyle {}T(x,y,z) = 5 e^{-2x^2 - y^2 - 3z^2}\), the gradient is

\[\begin{aligned} \nabla T(x,y,z) &= 5 e^{-2x^2 - y^2 - 3z^2}\left\langle{-4x, -2y, -6z}\right\rangle \\ &= 10e^{-2x^2 - y^2 - 3z^2}\left\langle{-2x, -y, -3z}\right\rangle\end{aligned}\]

At the point \(\displaystyle {}P(1,2,-1)\), we have \(\nabla T(1,2,-1) = 10 e^{-9}\left\langle{-2,-2,3}\right\rangle.\) Each component has units of \(\displaystyle {}\text{C}/\text{m}\).

The vector from \(\displaystyle {}P(1,2,-1)\) to \(\displaystyle {}Q(1,1,0)\) is \(\displaystyle {}\left\langle{0,-1,1}\right\rangle\)

A unit vector in this direction is

\[\begin{aligned} \widehat{\mathbf{u}} = \frac{\left\langle{0,-1,1}\right\rangle}{\left\vert\left\langle{0,-1,1}\right\rangle\right\vert} = \frac{1}{\sqrt2}\left\langle{0,-1,1}\right\rangle\end{aligned}\]

Each component is dimensionless because the units of the vector \(\mathbf{u}\) and its magnitude are the same.

The rate of change of T at P in direction \(\displaystyle {}\widehat{\mathbf{u}}\) is

\[\begin{aligned} D_{\widehat{\mathbf{u}}} T(1,2,-1) = \nabla T(1,2,-1)\cdot\widehat{\mathbf{u}} = 10 e^{-9}\left(\frac{5}{\sqrt2}\right) = 25\sqrt2 e^{-9}.\end{aligned}\]

Its units are \(\displaystyle {}\text{C}/\text{m}\).
sols_latex:
For $\displaystyle {}T(x,y,z) = 5 e^{-2x^2 - y^2 - 3z^2}$, the gradient
is

\begin{align*}
\nabla T(x,y,z) &= 5 e^{-2x^2 - y^2 - 3z^2}\left\langle{-4x, -2y, -6z}\right\rangle \\
&= 10e^{-2x^2 - y^2 - 3z^2}\left\langle{-2x, -y, -3z}\right\rangle
\end{align*}

At the point $\displaystyle {}P(1,2,-1)$, we have $\nabla T(1,2,-1)
= 10 e^{-9}\left\langle{-2,-2,3}\right\rangle.$ Each component has units
of $\displaystyle {}\text{C}/\text{m}$.

The vector from $\displaystyle {}P(1,2,-1)$ to $\displaystyle {}Q(1,1,0)$
is $\displaystyle {}\left\langle{0,-1,1}\right\rangle$

A unit vector in this direction is

\begin{align*}
\widehat{\mathbf{u}} = \frac{\left\langle{0,-1,1}\right\rangle}{\left\vert\left\langle{0,-1,1}\right\rangle\right\vert} = \frac{1}{\sqrt2}\left\langle{0,-1,1}\right\rangle
\end{align*}

Each component is dimensionless because the units of the vector
$\mathbf{u}$ and its magnitude are the same.

The rate of change of \emph{T} at \emph{P} in direction
$\displaystyle {}\widehat{\mathbf{u}}$ is

\begin{align*}
D_{\widehat{\mathbf{u}}} T(1,2,-1)
= \nabla T(1,2,-1)\cdot\widehat{\mathbf{u}}
= 10 e^{-9}\left(\frac{5}{\sqrt2}\right)
= 25\sqrt2 e^{-9}.
\end{align*} Its units are $\displaystyle {}\text{C}/\text{m}$.

:<math> \begin{align}
\nabla T(x,y,z) &= 5 e^{-2x^2 - y^2 - 3z^2}\left\langle{-4x, -2y, -6z}\right\rangle \\
&= 10e^{-2x^2 - y^2 - 3z^2}\left\langle{-2x, -y, -3z}\right\rangle
\end{align}
</math>

At the point <math>\displaystyle{}P(1,2,-1)</math>, we have
<math>
\nabla T(1,2,-1)
= 10 e^{-9}\left\langle{-2,-2,3}\right\rangle.
</math>
Each component has units of <math>\displaystyle{}\text{C}/\text{m}</math>.

The vector from <math>\displaystyle{}P(1,2,-1)</math> to <math>\displaystyle{}Q(1,1,0)</math> is <math>\displaystyle{}\left\langle{0,-1,1}\right\rangle</math>

A unit vector in this direction is
:<math>
\widehat{\mathbf{u}} = \frac{\left\langle{0,-1,1}\right\rangle}{\left\vert\left\langle{0,-1,1}\right\rangle\right\vert} = \frac{1}{\sqrt2}\left\langle{0,-1,1}\right\rangle
</math>

Each component is dimensionless because the units of the vector <math>\mathbf{u}</math> and its magnitude are the same.

The rate of change of ''T'' at ''P''
in direction <math>\displaystyle{}\widehat{\mathbf{u}}</math> is
:<math>\begin{align}
D_{\widehat{\mathbf{u}}} T(1,2,-1)
= \nabla T(1,2,-1)\cdot\widehat{\mathbf{u}}
= 10 e^{-9}\left(\frac{5}{\sqrt2}\right)
= 25\sqrt2 e^{-9}.
\end{align}
</math>
Its units are <math>\displaystyle{}\text{C}/\text{m}</math>.
statement_html:
The temperature at a point (x,y,z) is given by

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}T(x,y,z)=5\exp(-2x^2-y^2-3z^2)\end{aligned}\]

where T is measured in centigrade and x,y,z in metres.

Find the rate of change of temperature at the point P(1,2,-1) in the direction toward the point (1,1,0).
statement_latex:
The temperature at a point (x,y,z) is given by

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle{}T(x,y,z)=5\exp(-2x^2-y^2-3z^2)
\end{align*}

where T is measured in centigrade and x,y,z in metres.

Find the rate of change of temperature at the point P(1,2,-1) in the
direction toward the point (1,1,0).
statement_raw:
The temperature at a point (x,y,z) is given by

:<math>
\displaystyle{}T(x,y,z)=5\exp(-2x^2-y^2-3z^2)
</math>

where T is measured in centigrade and x,y,z in metres.

Find the rate of change of temperature at the point P(1,2,-1) in the direction toward the point (1,1,0).
